intro: Azalea arborea, commonly known as the tree azalea, is a flowering shrub native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Rhododendron genus and is characterized by its dense, evergreen foliage and showy clusters of bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows as a small tree or large shrub, reaching heights of up to 15 feet. Its flowers, which range in color from white to deep red, bloom in spring and are highly fragrant. Azalea arborea prefers acidic, well-drained soil and partial to full sunlight, making it a popular choice for ornamental landscaping.
